text: Hi all, I’m Farnaz Jahanbakhsh, and I’ll be presenting the paper Understanding Questions
that Arise When Working with Business Documents, that I worked on during my internship at Microsoft
Research along with my amazing mentors Elanz Nouri, Robert Sim, Ryen White, and Adam Fourney.
Many systems have been increasingly incorporating intelligent digital assistants to help people
be more productive, at home, as well as at work e.g., for scheduling meetings or for
managing task lists.
But one workplace area of interest that hasn’t seen much progress in this regard is documents.
An assistant in this context could help people consume written documents or perform complex
tasks on documents more quickly.
But to achieve this vision and build an agent that is prepared to handle a variety of requests
from the user, we first need to understand what types of assistance people would want
as they are working on their business documents.
Aren’t there already datasets for document Q&A that can tell us the types of assistance
people want?
Most datasets for document question answering contain factoid questions that were generated
by crowd workers who were given a collection of documents and were tasked with generating
questions for those.
And some datasets contain search queries on documents found on the Web.
Now why aren’t these enough for the context of a document assistant that we’re envisioning?
Because first, the documents in these datasets were in their final published form, and second,
query generators often assumed or had the role of “reader”, with only limited knowledge
of what the document contained.
And neither one of these is necessarily true when people are interacting with business
documents and need help with them.
Business documents could be under development and may not be finalized yet and the users
who need to work with these documents may have prior interactions with them, and may
not want to only read, but also review, or edit the document.
So to understand users’ actual needs in this setting, it’s important that we involve
authors, reviewers, and readers of such documents in the process of generating queries.
In addition, for these questions to have ecological validity, we need to collect them in-situ
as users are working on their documents and their information needs arise.
This brings us to two of our research questions: What types of document-related questions do
people desire support with from a digital assistant?
How are the distribution of questions different depending on whether the user is an author,
reviewer, or reader of the document?
We expected that answering some of the potential questions would be beyond the capabilities
of current systems and there may be a need for human intelligence.
We hypothesized that if a Q&A system in this domain were to be deployed to accommodate
user needs, at least for the present, it would need to incorporate human workers.
And that brings us to our 3rd research question: What skillsets and roles are needed from human
respondents to accommodate requests in a human-in-the-loop document Q&A assistant?
We conducted two user studies to answer our research questions.
In the first study, we used an experience-sampling method to collect users’ questions about
their documents.
This we did through a Microsoft word add-in that we built which at random points throughout
the day when a user was working on their document would prompt them and ask what question they
had about the document at that moment.
The prompt would also ask a few followup questions about the context.
E.g., who the user believed could answer their question best and how long it would take the
user themselves to answer the question.
In addition, we automatically collected some metadata about the document such as who the
author was and who was the most recent contributor.
Users could also submit a question whenever they wanted w/o having to wait for the prompt
or even refrain from answering when prompted.
We recruited 59 users who were employees of Microsoft to participate in this study.
They installed the add-in and submitted questions for a week.
The experience sampling in study 1 was a step along the path to our vision of a hybrid human-AI
document Q&A system.
We also wanted to explore our research questions in the context of an actual prototype of the
type of Q&A system that we ultimately envision.
So as a second study, we designed and developed a human-in-the-loop system that collected
users’ questions about their documents and provided responses to them.
This system consisted of an AI component and human workers who supervised the AI and answered
questions if the AI failed to provide a satisfactory answer.
In this study too, users submitted their questions about the document through a Word add-in.
With each question, users submitted a share link to the document if they consented to
the digital assistant or a human knowledge worker accessing the document to answer their
question.
Once a question had been answered, the answer would appear below the question in the Add-in
and the users would receive an email notification about the answer.
The knowledge workers’ view contained all the questions submitted by users.
As each question arrived, the workers performed the task of determining whether the question
was answerable, or the type of the question (e.g., if it was about the document’s content
or its metadata or its visual style and so on), whether there was any specific domain
knowledge needed to answer the question, etc.
The workers had different workflows for answering questions of different types.
For example, for answering content related questions, they would access the document
using the share link, copy paste the document’s text and the question into a custom UI front-end
for the ML Q&A model.
And would change the answer if it was unsatisfactory.
41 participants recruited from microsoft participated in this study and worked with the add-in for
2 weeks.
To answer our first research question about what types of questions people want assistance with, we
categorized the questions of both our studies based on what type of information they were
asking for and where that information was available.
Here’s the overview of the categories.
We had questions asking about the metadata of the document, others about how to perform
a specific task in Microsoft Word, questions about the content some of which required some
amount of reasoning, questions about the written or the visual style of the document, and questions
looking for information that was not even in the document and which could be found either
in public resources, or within the company, or which needed to be directed to domain experts,
and so on.
I encourage you to read about the full taxonomy in our paper.
What was interesting was that there were only a few questions that the AI could answer and
the rest had to be answered by human knowledge workers.
The types of questions that the AI could handle were limited to factual content-related questions
because for those the AI could retrieve a passage from the document.
The finding that the AI couldn’t handle most questions suggests that at least for
the present, the type of tool that we envision needs to employ a combination of automation
and human intelligence.
But the questions, documents, and the human generated responses of a hybrid Q&A system
can serve as ecologically valid training data for building future Q&A models.
To answer RQ2, we examined whether the types of questions a user asks about a document
vary by the user’s role in the document, e.g if they’re the author, a reviewer, or
a reader.
We found that the user’s role was in fact a factor in the type of questions that they
asked.
E.g., authors were often concerned with performing specific operations in Word or finding information
external to the document.
Readers interestingly also asked questions about external information but those information needs had
arisen because they had encountered something in the document’s content that they didn’t
have enough context for.
So, it’s not enough to only ask readers, or people unfamiliar with a document, about
their questions.
Their questions would be different from what users with other roles would ask.
Now about our third research question: We found that many of the questions that users
would want help with can’t be answered by an AI and that human knowledge has to be
incorporated into the document Q&A system that we envision at least for the present.
But who should the human respondents be and what kind of roles and skillsets should they
have?
In our study, the types of respondents needed included the document author, document collaborators
experts in various domains e.g., finance, legal, marketing, or software engineering.
and human workers with a more general skill set
So, a document assistant would need to classify and route questions to the appropriate respondents.
In our paper, we suggest ways this could be achieved.
In our paper, we further discuss opportunities for automating the handling of different types
of questions in this domain, as well as the opportunities and the potential challenges
of Incorporating Humans in the Loop in such a system.
I invite you to check out our paper to learn more.
